title: Specifying `no_std` with `extern crate std` does not import `core`
body:
I'm trying to have `std` imported conditionally for testing only, as I use `core` in my OS kernel, and found this issue. This minimal code:

```
#![feature(no_std)]
#![no_std]
extern crate std;

#[derive(Copy)]
pub enum Kind {
    None = 0,
    Reserved = 1,
}
```

Gives errors on `cargo build`:

```
   Compiling example v0.0.1 (file:///home/virtlink/projects/example)
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 error: failed to resolve. Maybe a missing `extern crate core`?
src/lib.rs:5 #[derive(Copy)]
                      ^~~~
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 note: in expansion of #[derive_Copy]
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 note: expansion site
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 error: use of undeclared trait name `core::marker::Copy`
src/lib.rs:5 #[derive(Copy)]
                      ^~~~
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 note: in expansion of #[derive_Copy]
src/lib.rs:5:10: 5:14 note: expansion site
error: aborting due to 2 previous errors
Could not compile `example`.
```

However, if you remove the top three lines and let `std` be imported implicitly, then it works. For some reason the explicit `extern crate std` behaves differently from the implicit `std` import, which I did not expect.

I can't (and wouldn't expect to have to) do `extern crate core` explicitly, due to issue #23983.
